awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mercury Oxidation Pathways in a Continental Atmosphere: High Temporal Resolution Measurements of Mercury and Oxidants at Storm Peak Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on the study of atmospheric mercury. Mercury in the atmosphere exists in the gas-phase elemental form, as gas-phase oxidized mercury compounds, and bound to particles. The primary effort of this research will be on processes and mechanisms that govern oxidation reactions in the remote continental atmosphere. Mercury is a toxin that impacts neurological health and development in humans. A more thorough understanding of the atmospheric concentrations and chemical pathways of oxidized mercury is central to fully determining its fate. 

There are three objectives to this project: (1) Generate a high-quality dataset with accurate concentrations of elemental and oxidized mercury, halogen oxide radicals, aerosol size distribution, and other oxidants at a remote mountaintop site over the continental U.S.; (2) Identify the chemical mechanisms and physical processes that influence elemental and oxidized mercury in the free troposphere and the planetary boundary layer air masses; and (3) Bolster existing long-term measurements at Storm Peak Laboratory (e.g., to inform sources of new particle formation) and facilitate dialogue with researchers at other mountain observatories by sharing data analysis tools and expertise on best practices for sampling oxidized mercury, nanoparticles, and halogens from high elevation ground-based platforms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Field-measurements at the remote high-elevation Storm Peak Laboratory began in spring 2021 and concluded in fall 2022. From this sampling period, we generated two continuous and quality-assured datasets that included: elemental and oxidized mercury, trace gases (ozone, nitrogen oxides, sulfur dioxide, and carbon monoxide), aerosol properties (e.g. scattering, absorption, size distribution), and meteorological parameters (e.g. temperature, relative humidity, wind speed and direction) spanning the spring-summer seasons. Remote sensing methods were also used to retrieve atmospheric profiles of halogens and other trace species during these periods. The data are publicly available and represent some of the most comprehensive measurements of their kind from Storm Peak Lab.

Notably, this project supported the development and deployment of an improved, ground-based dual-channel measurement system for elemental and oxidized mercury at 10-minute time resolution that was field- and laboratory-validated using an automated calibrator. The result is a more accurate, quantitative, and higher time resolution set of continuous ambient mercury measurements as compared to previous studies. With these data, we performed a range of statistical and modeling analyses to characterize the origins and chemical behavior of atmospheric mercury at Storm Peak Lab. For example, we identified 18 multi-day events of elevated oxidized mercury that occurred in air with low relative humidity (32 ± 16%), oxidized-to-elemental mercury slopes of -0.39 ± 0.14, and simulated air mass transport consistently from the low- to mid-free troposphere. We examined the air mass composition during these events using concurrent trace gas and meteorological measurements, and also applied Principal Components factor analysis to each season of data collection. We concluded that the concentrations of oxidized mercury observed at Storm Peak Lab were the result of upwind oxidation in the free troposphere with partial loss during transport to the continental measurement site. Notably, elemental mercury concentrations were lower than previous measurements at Storm Peak Lab by approximately 0.3 ng m-3 possibly due to a decline in the Northern Hemisphere background, whereas oxidized mercury concentrations were approximately three times higher than this earlier work due to the improved measurement accuracy of the dual-channel system. Other analyses utilizing the Storm Peak dataset have compared observations with chemical models, explored the role of different oxidants in atmospheric mercury chemistry in the troposphere and lower stratosphere, and investigated the relative mercury and trace gas enhancements in wildfire plumes. Findings have been presented at national and international professional meetings, and are forthcoming in the peer-reviewed literature.

The project also importantly bolstered activities at Storm Peak Laboratory, fostered conversations with other experts, and offered mentorship and participation opportunities for undergraduate students. For example, in addition to disseminating results at major professional meetings, we invited several established scientists in the mercury biogeochemistry community to attend the project’s two data workshops, where they shared their own related work and offered outside perspectives on directions for ongoing research. This project also supported the mentorship of four undergraduate students at Colorado College, a Primarily Undergraduate Institution, who all participated in summer research experiences and subsequently wrote senior theses using data generated from the field campaigns. These students presented findings at local and/or national conferences, and two have directly contributed to manuscript preparation. They received formal and informal mentorship from the other three principal investigators on the project, including each of those faculty serving as a second reader on one of the undergraduate theses. The project additionally supported the participation of undergraduate and graduate students at the three collaborating institutions, directly contributing to two Master’s theses and one doctoral thesis. Furthermore, this collaboration inspired the development of an atmospheric chemistry field course for undergraduate students at Colorado College that was separately supported by the NSF FARE program. A public lecture was also given in Steamboat Springs, CO to inform the local community about research activities at Storm Peak Lab related to this and other projects. Principal investigators also shared preliminary project results with students participating in the University of Utah Department of Atmospheric Sciences summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) during a site visit to Storm Peak, further broadening the exposure of this work to early career researchers.

In summary, the recent measurements at Storm Peak Laboratory using the dual-channel system represent a significant contribution to the research field in the ability to report verified, accurate, and reliably higher oxidized mercury concentration measurements than in past studies. The principal investigators hope that this methodology will continue to advance in its development, and also be adopted by more researchers in the community. Going forward, this project has the potential to foster ongoing collaborations between the principal investigators related to high altitude atmospheric observations and mercury oxidation chemistry, and/or to initiate new collaborations with colleagues who have supported or engaged with this work along the way.
